title: create-join-column
text: vignette walks create_join_column() function, used creating new columns dfdiffs shiny application.
code: library(shiny) library(tidyverse) library(purrr) library(vroom) library(reactable) library(haven) library(readxl)

title: create-join-column
text: function allows us create new ‘join’ column number column inputs.
code: create_join_column <- function(df, join_cols, new_col_name){   # select by_vars   tmp <- select(df, all_of(join_cols))   # convert to character   tmp <- mutate(tmp, across(.fns = as.character))   # rename data    join_col_data <- df   # assign new col   join_col_data$new_col <- pmap_chr(.l = tmp, .f = paste, sep = "-")   # rename    names(join_col_data)[names(join_col_data) == "new_col"] <- new_col_name   # relocate   join_col_data <- relocate(join_col_data, all_of(new_col_name))   # return   return(join_col_data) }

text: also need function allows users specify joining variables, creates new join_var given supplied columns constitute unique identifier dataset. example, T1Data T2Data, can create unique identifier named join_var
code: T1DataJoin <- mutate(T1Data,    join_var = as.character(row_number())) %>%    dplyr::relocate(join_var, everything()) T2DataJoin <- mutate(T2Data,    join_var = as.character(row_number())) %>%    dplyr::relocate(join_var, everything()) T1DataJoin T2DataJoin

title: create-new-data
text: Two datasets, compare columns: Multiple columns compare (cols): Single column, new column name Single column, new column name (by_col) Single column, multiple compare columns cols Single column, new column name (by_col), multiple compare columns (cols)
code: create_new_data(   compare = T2Data,    base = T1Data) create_new_data(   compare = T2Data,    base = T1Data,   cols = c("text_var", "factor_var")) create_new_data(   compare = T2DataJoin,    base = T1DataJoin,    by = "join_var") create_new_data(   compare = T2DataJoin,    base = T1DataJoin,    by = "join_var",    by_col = 'new_join_var') create_new_data(   compare = T2DataJoin,    base = T1DataJoin,    by = "join_var",    cols = c("text_var", "factor_var", "subject", "record")) create_new_data( compare = T2DataJoin,  base = T1DataJoin,  # unique id by = "join_var",  # new name for id by_col = 'new_join_var',  # cols to compare cols = c("subject", "record", "text_var", "factor_var"))

title: create-new-data
text: Multiple columns Multiple columns, new column name (by_col) Multiple columns, multiple compare columns (cols) Multiple columns, new by_col, cols
code: create_new_data(   compare = T2Data,    base = T1Data,    by = c('subject', 'record')) create_new_data(   compare = T2Data,    base = T1Data,    by = c('subject', 'record'),   by_col = "new_join_col") create_new_data(   compare = T2Data,    base = T1Data,    by = c('subject', 'record'),   cols = c("subject",  "record", "factor_var", "text_var")) create_new_data(   compare = T2Data,    base = T1Data,    by = c('subject', 'record'),   by_col = "new_join_col",   cols = c("subject", "record", "text_var", "factor_var"))

code: create_new_data(compare, base, by = NULL, by_col = NULL, cols = NULL)

code: library(dplyr) library(stringr) library(forcats) library(lubridate) library(fs) library(vctrs) library(glue) library(purrr) library(vroom) library(haven) library(readxl) library(dfdiffs) library(kableExtra)

title: modified-data
text: ChangedData data unique identifier, can create one create_join_column() function. InitialDataID ChangedDataID
code: ChangedData <- dfdiffs::ChangedData InitialDataID <- create_join_column(df = InitialData,    by_colums = c('subject_id', 'record'),    new_by_column_name = 'subrecid') ChangedDataID <- create_join_column(df = ChangedData,    by_colums = c('subject_id', 'record'),    new_by_column_name = 'subrecid')

title: modified-data
text: create_modified_data() function wrapper around arsenal::comparedf(), returns small fraction output. function also requires call summary() clean output bit. ’re interested diffs.byvar.table diffs.table.
code: modified_cdf <- arsenal::comparedf(   x = ChangedDataID,   y = InitialDataID,    by = "subrecid") modified_cdf_sum <- summary(modified_cdf) names(modified_cdf_sum) #> [1] "frame.summary.table"      "comparison.summary.table" #> [3] "vars.ns.table"            "vars.nc.table"            #> [5] "obs.table"                "diffs.byvar.table"        #> [7] "diffs.table"              "attrs.table"              #> [9] "control"

title: multiple-comparisons
text: package Similar packages

title: multiple-comparisons
text: folder structure datasets separated year. start storing files vector list.files(), clean names bit, pass list paths readr::read_csv purrr::map():
code: fs::dir_tree("../inst/extdata/csv/by-year") #> ../inst/extdata/csv/by-year #> ├── 20 #> │   ├── PlayerBirth.csv #> │   ├── PlayerDeath.csv #> │   └── PlayerName.csv #> └── 21 #>     ├── PlayerBirth.csv #>     ├── PlayerDeath.csv #>     └── PlayerName.csv base_files <- list.files(path = "../inst/extdata/csv/by-year/20",    pattern = ".csv", recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE) base_files_nms <- map_chr(base_files, base::basename) base_dfs <- base_files |>    purrr::set_names(base_files_nms) |>    purrr::map(readr::read_csv) compare_files <- list.files(path = "../inst/extdata/csv/by-year/21",    pattern = ".csv", recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE) compare_files_nms <- map_chr(compare_files, base::basename) compare_dfs <- compare_files |>    purrr::set_names(compare_files_nms) |>    purrr::map(readr::read_csv)

title: multiple-comparisons
text: ’re going follow iteration steps Charlotte Wickham’s Happy R Users Purrr Tutorial ONE TURN RECIPE !

title: multiple-comparisons
text: ’re going use arsenal::comparedf() function first. Remember function requires additional summary() call!

title: multiple-comparisons
code: by_var <- "playerID" cdf_people <- arsenal::comparedf(   x = base_dfs$PlayerName.csv,    y = compare_dfs$PlayerName.csv,    by = by_var) sumcdf_people <- summary(cdf_people) names(sumcdf_people) #> [1] "frame.summary.table"      "comparison.summary.table" #> [3] "vars.ns.table"            "vars.nc.table"            #> [5] "obs.table"                "diffs.byvar.table"        #> [7] "diffs.table"              "attrs.table"              #> [9] "control"

title: multiple-comparisons
text: Next ’ll use diffdf::diffdf() function. Just ensure ’re getting display output functions, ’re going use diffs.byvar.table/NumDiff tables, diffs.table/ VarDiff_ tables.
code: diffdf_people <- diffdf::diffdf(   compare = compare_dfs$PlayerName.csv,    base = base_dfs$PlayerName.csv,    keys = "playerID") diffdf_people |> names() #> [1] "ExtRowsBase"       "NumDiff"           "VarDiff_nameFirst" #> [4] "VarDiff_nameLast"  "VarDiff_nameGiven"

previous_headings: Do it for one (or two) > diffdf::diffdf

text: diffs.byvar.table
code: sumcdf_people[["diffs.byvar.table"]] |>    select(Variable = var.x,           `No of Differences` = n) |>    knitr::kable(caption = "diffs.byvar.table") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper()

previous_headings: Do it for one (or two) > diffdf::diffdf
title: multiple-comparisons
text: NumDiff
code: diffdf_people[["NumDiff"]] |>    knitr::kable(caption = "NumDiff") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper()

text: diffs.table
code: sumcdf_people[["diffs.table"]] |>    unnest(values.x) |>    unnest(values.y) |>    select(     VARIABLE = var.x,     all_of(by_var),     BASE = values.x,     COMPARE = values.y   ) |>    knitr::kable(caption = "diffs.table") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper()

previous_headings: Do it for one (or two) > diffdf::diffdf

title: similar-work
text: check new data, ’re going use T1Data T2Data. create_new_data() function shows us ‘new data’ (.e. now wasn’t ?) can check NewData dataset (match output create_new_data()) New data T1 > T2 New data (Comparison) can see differences datasets formats date columns:
code: T1Data <- dfdiffs::T1Data T2Data <- dfdiffs::T2Data T1T2New <- create_new_data(compare = T2Data, base = T1Data) T1T2New |>    knitr::kable(caption = "New data T1 > T2") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper() NewData <- dfdiffs::NewData NewData |>    knitr::kable(caption = "New data (Comparison)") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper() waldo::compare(x = T1T2New, y = NewData) #> `old$start_date` is a character vector ('2022-04-04', '2022-04-02', '2022-04-04') #> `new$start_date` is an S3 object of class <Date>, a double vector #>  #> `old$mid_date` is a character vector ('2022-04-13', '2022-04-14', '2022-04-15') #> `new$mid_date` is an S3 object of class <Date>, a double vector #>  #> `old$end_date` is a character vector ('2022-04-22', '2022-04-20', '2022-04-21') #> `new$end_date` is an S3 object of class <Date>, a double vector

title: similar-work
text: test deleted data, use CompleteData, IncompleteData, DeletedData. CompleteData represents ‘complete’ set data, CompleteData IncompleteData dataset rows removed CompleteData. IncompleteData run create_deleted_data(), check deleted rows IncompleteData CompleteData. IncompCompDiff identical data stored DeletedData DeletedData
code: CompleteData <- dfdiffs::CompleteData CompleteData |>    knitr::kable(caption = "CompleteData") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper() IncompleteData <- dfdiffs::IncompleteData IncompleteData |>    knitr::kable(caption = "IncompleteData") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper() IncompCompDiff <- create_deleted_data(   compare = IncompleteData,    base = CompleteData) |>    arrange(subject) IncompCompDiff |>    knitr::kable(caption = "IncompCompDiff") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper() DeletedData <- dfdiffs::DeletedData DeletedData |>    knitr::kable(caption = "DeletedData") |>    kableExtra::kable_paper() waldo::compare(x = IncompCompDiff, y = DeletedData) #> `old$record` is a character vector ('2', '3', '1', '1') #> `new$record` is an integer vector (2, 3, 1, 1) #>  #> `old$start_date` is a character vector ('2021-12-28', '2021-12-26', '2021-12-30', '2021-12-27') #> `new$start_date` is an S3 object of class <Date>, a double vector #>  #> `old$mid_date` is a character vector ('2022-01-27', '2022-01-25', '2022-01-29', '2022-01-26') #> `new$mid_date` is an S3 object of class <Date>, a double vector #>  #> `old$end_date` is a character vector ('2022-02-26', '2022-02-24', '2022-02-28', '2022-02-25') #> `new$end_date` is an S3 object of class <Date>, a double vector

title: upload-data
text: load_flat_file() function imports forms flat data files. file excel file, name sheet passed sheet.
code: load_flat_file <- function(path) {   ext <- tools::file_ext(path)   data <- switch(ext,     txt = data.table::fread(path),     csv = data.table::fread(path),     tsv = data.table::fread(path),     sas7bdat = haven::read_sas(data_file = path),     sas7bcat = haven::read_sas(data_file = path),     sav = haven::read_sav(file = path),     dta = haven::read_dta(file = path)   )   return_data <- tibble::as_tibble(data)   return(return_data) } upload_data <- function(path, sheet = NULL) {   ext <- tools::file_ext(path)   if (ext == "xlsx") {     raw_data <- readxl::read_excel(         path = path,         sheet = sheet       )     uploaded <- tibble::as_tibble(raw_data)   } else {     uploaded <- load_flat_file(path = path)   }   return(uploaded) }

title: upload-data
text: Now create lahman_2010_csv_files ’ll test map_df() function.
code: lahman_2010_csv_files <- map(.x = lahman_2010_csv_paths,    .f = load_flat_file) %>%    set_names(x = ., nm = basename(lahman_2010_csv_paths)) map(lahman_2010_csv_files, names) #> $Batting.csv #>  [1] "playerID"  "yearID"    "stint"     "teamID"    "lgID"      "G"         #>  [7] "G_batting" "AB"        "R"         "H"         "2B"        "3B"        #> [13] "HR"        "RBI"       "SB"        "CS"        "BB"        "SO"        #> [19] "IBB"       "HBP"       "SH"        "SF"        "GIDP"      "G_old"     #>  #> $Fielding.csv #>  [1] "playerID" "yearID"   "stint"    "teamID"   "lgID"     "POS"      #>  [7] "G"        "GS"       "InnOuts"  "PO"       "A"        "E"        #> [13] "DP"       "PB"       "WP"       "SB"       "CS"       "ZR"       #>  #> $Master.csv #>  [1] "lahmanID"     "playerID"     "managerID"    "hofID"        "birthYear"    #>  [6] "birthMonth"   "birthDay"     "birthCountry" "birthState"   "birthCity"    #> [11] "deathYear"    "deathMonth"   "deathDay"     "deathCountry" "deathState"   #> [16] "deathCity"    "nameFirst"    "nameLast"     "nameNote"     "nameGiven"    #> [21] "nameNick"     "weight"       "height"       "bats"         "throws"       #> [26] "debut"        "finalGame"    "college"      "lahman40ID"   "lahman45ID"   #> [31] "retroID"      "holtzID"      "bbrefID" tbl_2010_csv_files <- lahman_2010_csv_paths %>%    set_names() %>%    map_df(.x = .,    .f = load_flat_file, .id = "source") %>%    mutate(source = basename(source)) tbl_2010_csv_files %>% count(source) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   source            n #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 Batting.csv   93955 #> 2 Fielding.csv 160710 #> 3 Master.csv    17674

title: Data Frame Differences (What's New, Deleted, and Changed?)
text: goal dfdiffs answer following questions: rows now weren’t ? rows aren’t now? values changed? can access development version application .

code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("mjfrigaard/dfdiffs")

code: library(dfdiffs) library(dplyr) library(stringr) library(forcats) library(lubridate) library(fs) library(vctrs) library(glue) library(purrr) library(vroom) library(haven) library(readxl) library(janitor)  library(arsenal)  library(diffdf)   library(gt) library(labelled) library(gtsummary)
